case_title: Mst. SHAZIA PARVEEN vs MUHAMMAD ASHRAF

accussed_details.name: Muhammad Ashraf
allegation: Filed suit for restitution of conjugal rights

complaint_summary: Mst. Shazia Parveen filed a suit for dissolution of marriage due to estrangement. Muhammad Ashraf filed a counter-suit for restitution of conjugal rights.
investigation_summary: The respondent, Muhammad Ashraf, failed to appear despite repeated notices served through registered cover, telegraphic communication, and ordinary process.
judgment_summary: The court granted the petition filed by Mst. Shazia Parveen, transferring Muhammad Ashraf's suit for restitution of conjugal rights from Faisalabad to Lahore for adjudication alongside her dissolution of marriage suit.
legal_arguments: Petitioner argued for transfer to avoid contradictory judgments and for convenience.
Respondent failed to contest the petition, leading to an ex parte decision.

legal_terms.Rukhasti: A customary practice in South Asian marriages referring to the bride's departure to her husband's home.

words_and_phrases.Ex parte: A legal proceeding conducted for the benefit of one party due to the absence of the other.

summary_vector_notes: The case involves a matrimonial dispute where the petitioner sought dissolution of marriage, and the respondent filed a counter-suit for restitution of conjugal rights. The court transferred the respondent's suit to Lahore for adjudication alongside the petitioner's suit, citing convenience and avoidance of contradictory judgments. The respondent failed to appear despite multiple notices, leading to an ex parte decision.

facts.estrangement_reason: Rukhasti deferred and did not mature

appellant_suit.title: Mst. Shazia Parveen v. Muhammad Ashraf

petition_details.reason_for_transfer: Feminine convenience and avoidance of contradictory judgments
petition_details.respondent_status: Did not join proceedings, proceeded ex parte
petition_details.decision: Suit transferred from Faisalabad to Lahore
